awd_titl_txt: Next generation informatics to elucidate viral ecology and ecosystem impacts in nature
awd_abstract_narration:
Microbes are now appreciated for their roles in human health and disease, in promoting plant growth, and cycling nutrients in the oceans and soils. More recently, it has been recognized that the viruses that infect these microbes influence both the microbes and their communities through selective killing, moving genes between them, and reprogramming their host's metabolism during infection. Because viruses are so tiny, and most cannot be currently grown in laboratories, we are reliant upon decoding their biology through "reading" their stories via molecular sequencing techniques. This project seeks to augment iVirus, a collection of software tools (apps) and databases that leverages the NSF-funded CyVerse CyberInfrastructure (CI) to help researchers store, read and interpret these viral stories. Through development of new apps and curation of existing databases, the project will establish new analyses and features for researchers, directly train several undergraduate students, graduate students, and postdocs, and will provide two international training workshops to better "see" the viruses in their research.

The microbiome is increasingly recognized to drive the nutrient and energy cycles that fuel Earth's diverse ecosystems, with their viruses modulating these impacts through killing, horizontal gene transfer, and metabolic reprogramming during infection. With the recent emergence of quantitative, sequence-based methods to comprehensively explore virus diversity in nature, the precise roles that viruses play can be increasingly elucidated. To perform these analyses, the iVirus platform was established in 2017 as part of the NSF-funded CyVerse CyberInfrastructure. iVirus currently includes apps, databases, and live documentation designed to enable researchers to better identify and analyze virus sequences by integrating and enhancing access to (meta)genomic sequence datasets and functions in the context of the NSF-funded CyVerse CyberInfrastructure. This project seeks to significantly augment iVirus in three ways: (i) aggregate and upgrade current viral ecogenomic capabilities, (ii) develop an integrated viral ecogenomic analytical pipeline, and (iii) establish direct connections and inter-operability across key databases and independent cyberinfrastructure environments. Beyond augmenting iVirus capabilities at CyVerse, we will actively seek to maximize its impact and utility for researchers through key partnerships with other existing tools (e.g., DOE Joint Genome Institute IMG/VR database). We will also continue to collect and be responsive to feedback provided through the CyVerse and the protocols.io reporting platforms, as well as collaborator and general user beta-testing and subsequent feedback on releases. Finally, we'll provide training at all levels through peer-reviewed publications, talks, and dedicated international workshops to enable the broader research community. The results of this project can be found at the iVirus website, http://ivirus.us/ .

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Microbes play important roles in natural ecosystems. For example, some can decompose plant litter, while others convert nitrogen into a bio-available form. All together, microbes are central to cycling nutrients and help balance ecosystems all over our planet. However, while viruses prey on these microbes (called phages), their diversity and ecosystem roles are much less known. In the oceans, tracer experiments tell us that phages kill about one-third of all microbial cells per day. This impacts nutrient cycling, but also can lead to shuffling millions of microbial genes from one cell to another and to infected cells that release completely different molecules into the ecosystem than their uninfected sister cells. Problematically, studying viruses in nature requires sequencing and bioinformatics to see these viruses and most of these viruses are not known to science. Challenges include estimating the number of species present, their abundance, the roles of the genes they carry, and how these metrics correlate with other environmental factors. Together, such analyses comprise a long-sought ?ecogenomic? toolkit that would better reveal the impact of viruses in complex ecosystems. 

This NSF-funded project had three major goals: 1) to upgrade available and develop new ecogenomic tools for studying viruses, 2) to develop ecogenomic analytical standards, and 3) to facilitate the adoption of these tools via engagement events such as workshops and webinars. For the first aim, major updates were successfully developed for three tools: vConTACT2, VirSorter2, and MArVD2. Briefly, vConTACT2 is a genome-based classification that allows the user to classify any phage genome based on gene clusters, and this second version permits the classification of thousands of phage genomes at a time, greatly reducing processing time. VirSorter2 is a tool for the identification of virus sequences in any dataset. It can also be ?trained? by users to recognize certain categories of viruses to better suit their needs. Lastly, MArVD2 enables the identification of a specific group of viruses that infect Archaea, and was trained with a new database to increase its performance and specificity.  

For the second aim, four new products were developed. DRAM-v is a tool that can be used to identify auxiliary metabolic genes within virus genomes. These genes are typically derived from the host of the virus, and have been co-opted by the virus to enhance its survival fitness. Without laboratory cultivation, it has remained a grand challenge to predict the host of the viruses that are sequenced from environmental samples. To that end, we developed VirMatcher - a tool that enables the user to predict the bacterial host of the phage based on genome sequence alone. To further enhance the identification and annotation of unknown viruses from marine samples, we developed a new database made up of hidden markov models (HMMs) derived from >200,000 virus genomes that we have previously identified. Lastly, to streamline sequence data processing and basic ecological analysis, we release MetaPop, a simple-to-use tool that requires minimal user input, and outputs a number of useful files that greatly facilitates downstream analysis. In addition to these tools, a paper was published aimed at spreading awareness about the new and improved viromics toolkit. Taken together, this set of analytical tools significantly augments the viromics toolkit available to the research community. These works have resulted in 6 publications (including Nature Biotechnology and Microbiome), which have been well received as collectively they total 822 citations since 2019.

In parallel to these developments, and as part of aim 3, we have engaged extensively with the research community in several impactful ways, including: holding a 3-day hybrid workshop (34 students, 179 online participants, and 10 teachers), created a YouTube channel (5.4K views) that hosts 35 webinars from two ?microbiome webinar series? that we organized and hosted to bring users to these tools, keeping an updated iVirus website (https://www.ivirus.us/), step-by-step informatics protocols via protocols.io (>39K views). These combined efforts represent a multi-pronged approach to outreach and education and have together led to hundreds of researchers using our customizable and modular iVirus toolkit at the NSF CyVerse collaborative cyberinfrastructure. Because these users span viral ecologists and microbiome scientists, we hope that researcher's abilities to ?see? viruses across diverse ecosystems on the planet are now greatly improved.
